questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of dark urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she has an icterus but normal mental status. Laboratory findings include a hematocrit of 26%, reticulocyte count of 5%, platelets at 130,000, ALP of 30 IU/L, ALT of 110 IU/L, AST of 220 IU/L, total bilirubin of 13 mg/dL, negative HBsAg, and a negative urine drug screen. An abdominal ultrasound shows a nodular liver and an enlarged spleen. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with lab findings of low hematocrit value, elevated reticulocyte count, and increased indirect bilirubin may point to copper-induced hemolysis, which is indicative of Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase found in cell membranes. Clinical manifestations include hepatitis, cirrhosis, behavioural changes, wing-beating tremors, and ophthalmic features such as copper deposition in the posterior lens capsule, leading to sunflower cataracts and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings.

The laboratory findings of Wilson’s disease include:

  • Low hematocrit value, increased reticulocyte – Indicative of hemolytic anaemia.
  • Unconjugated jaundice – Hemolytic anaemia and defective conjugation in the liver.
  • Mild elevation in the level of aminotransferase.
  • Nodular liver – Indicating a chronic condition.

Diagnosis is made by the presence of KF rings, decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels, liver biopsy and increased 24-hour urine copper excretion.

Trientine and Zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease. 

Other options :

Option A: Acetaminophen intoxication is ruled out since the Urinary screen is negative.

Option B: Acute viral hepatitis can be ruled out since there is a nodular liver indicative of cirrhosis and an enlarged spleen which implies chronicity. Aminotransferases are not grossly elevated.

Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) can also be ruled out since Alkaline phosphatase activity is normal. Additionally, there is no mention of mitochondrial antibody screening. History is not a characteristic of PBC.

questions.text: Criteria for weaning a patient on mechanical ventilation include all except_____

choices.text: Inspiratory pressure of −25 cm H 2 O

questions.solution:
Weaning off mechanical ventilation is indicated when vital capacity is >10 mL/kg.

All the other options are correct.

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of respiratory distress, intermittent abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, absent breath sounds in both sides of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the most common variant being Bochdalek hernia.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia. 

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

Other options:

Option B: Chest radiograph revealing bowel loops in the thorax is not seen in pneumonia.

Option C: Morgagni hernia: Here the defect is at the anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent paracardiac shadow may be seen retrosternally on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of omentum or solid organs.(Shown below)

 

Option D: Eventration of the diaphragm: It refers to the abnormal contour of the dome of the diaphragm without any disruption to the diaphragmatic continuity. It usually involves a segment of the hemidiaphragm. It can cause respiratory distress in newborns and is usually asymptomatic in adults.

Radiographic findings: The affected portion of the hemidiaphragm is elevated and is seen as a smooth hump, while the normal contour is seen in the remaining part. 'Double diaphragmatic contour' may be seen in frontal view and is confirmed with a lateral X-ray.

Image showing eventration of the right dome of the diaphragm-

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a child with the features shown in the given image. On examination, the child had brittle bones, and x-ray scans revealed stippled epiphyses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in causing this teratogenic condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose). This image along with the stippling of bone epiphyses points to fetal warfarin syndrome or warfarin embryopathy. 

Features:

  • Repeated abortions
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Depressed nasal bridge/absent nasal bone/saddle nose at birth
  • Bleeding diathesis at birth
  • Growth retardation - hypoplasia of nose, eye sockets, and long bones with stippling of epiphyses 

Anticoagulation in pregnancy:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, it can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus but is less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: It is inadequate, and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If delivery occurs while the anticoagulant is still effective, and excessive bleeding happens, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

Anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week of gestation. 
  • Heparin is then replaced by a warfarin tablet of 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks in patients with a high risk of thrombosis.
  • Thereafter, warfarin is replaced by heparin, which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH), LMWH, and warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: A 56-year-old man suffering from diabetes mellitus for 10 years came for a routine checkup. His lipid profile revealed increased TG (triacylglycerol) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). What is the cause of this abnormal lipid profile?

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.solution:
In chronic diabetes, the value of TG and VLDL are increased due to an increase in hormone-sensitive lipase and a decrease in lipoprotein lipase.

Insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in HSL activity. This promotes the breakdown of lipids and a release of TG and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and the degradation of the transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to an increase in VLDL and TG.

Related Pearl: Hormone sensitive lipase Vs lipoprotein lipase

   HSL  Lipoprotein lipase
Location  Adipocyte  Capillaries
Action  Hydrolyse TAG in adipose   tissue  Hydrolyse TAG in chylomicron , VLDL
Acts in the state of  Fasting (Glucagon)  Fed (Insulin)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best imaging modality to diagnose neuroendocrine tumours(NETs)?
questions.solution:
Positron emission tomography (PET) is the best modality to diagnose Neuroendocrine tumors(NETs).

The initial imaging investigation is standard cross-sectional imaging with computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In patients of suspected NETs, CTs of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis are done for staging, and consideration of an MRI of the liver or pancreas in cases where further definition is required.

PET scans with 111In (indium) labeled pentetreotide somatostatin and 68Ga (gallium) linked somatostatin analogues take advantage of the overexpression of somatostatin receptors commonly seen in NETs. These radiolabeled somatostatin analogues localized with PET scan are the best imaging modality for NETs.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum and the right testis has gone up. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with negative cremasteric reflex and positive Deming's sign (right testes gone up) is suggestive of testicular torsion.

Etiology and risk factors- 

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis(like a clapper in a bell). Most common cause.
  • Inversion of the testis.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are - scrotal pain and swelling, erythema, negative cremasteric reflex, nausea, and vomiting, testis seems high in the scrotum and twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

  • Prehn’s Sign is used to differentiate the torsion of testis from acute epididymo orchitis. In the case of acute epididymo orchitis, the pain gets relieved on the elevation of the testis but not in torsion of testes.
  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle and the cord twisting cause the affected testis to be positioned higher in torsion testes.

Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false-positives are high.

Urgent scrotal exploration in case of doubtful diagnosis.  A transverse scrotal incision is taken. If the testis is viable, twisting is prevented by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe.

Differential diagnosis -

  • Epididymo-orchitis - Here dysuria associated with the accompanying urinary infection is commonly present. In epididymo-orchitis elevation of the testis reduces the pain while it makes it worse in torsion. 
  • Torsion of a testicular appendage - Here the most common structure to twist is the appendix of the testis, which can be visible as a small dark spot. In most cases, it is indistinguishable from torsion testis. Hence in cases of doubt surgical exploration is done.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the ​Chicago classification, the patient has which type of achalasia?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of type III achalasia cardia.

Chicago classification of oesophageal motility describes the criteria for three types of achalasia cardia and other disorders associated with EGJ obstruction.

Chicago type I (Classic achalasia): It is characterised by hypomotile esophageal body. The criteria include:

  • Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg).
  • 100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mmHg·s·cm).
  • Premature contractions with DCI values <450 mmHg·s·cm satisfy criteria for failed peristalsis.

Chicago type II (with oesophageal compression): It is characterised by simultaneous tonic contraction after swallowing. The criteria include:

  • Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg).
  • 100% failed peristalsis.
  • Panoesophageal pressurisation with ≥20% of swallows.
  • Contractions may be masked by oesophageal pressurisation and DCI should not be calculated.

Chicago type III (spastic achalasia): It is characterised by massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus. The criteria include:

  • Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg).
  • No normal peristalsis.
  • Premature (spastic) contractions with DCI >450 mmHg·s·cm with ≥20% of swallows.
  • May be mixed with panoesophageal pressurisation.

questions.text: A corpse is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death in a case where the ligature is completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid, with no saliva dribbling, is ligature strangulation.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

Option C: Gagging is a type of asphyxia due to forcible closure of the mouth by a cloth or closing the mouth and nose and is tied around the head. 

Option D: Hanging is characterized by an incomplete and oblique ligature mark on the neck. It is usually seen higher, between the chin and larynx. Saliva often dribbles from the mouth.

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Trait

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Nature of death

Mostly suicidal

Mostly homicidal

Face

Usually pale and petechiae rare

Congested, livid and marked with petechiae

Tongue

Swelling and protrusion is less marked

Swelling and protrusion is more marked

Bleeding

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears not common

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears may be found

Saliva

Often dribbles out of the mouth

Such dribbling is very rare

Ligature mark

Oblique, non-continuous, placed high up in the neck between the chin and the larynx. 

The subcutaneous tissue underneath the mark is usually hard, white and glistening

Horizontal or transverse, continuous around the neck, low down in the neck below or across the thyroid.   

Subcutaneous tissue underneath may be ecchymosed

Abrasions and

ecchymoses

Rare

Common

Injury to muscles of

neck

Rare

Common

Carotid arteries

Internal coats usually ruptured in violent cases of a long drops(Amussat's sign)

Damage to internal coat is rare

Hyoid bone

Fracture of the hyoid bone less common

Fracture of the hyoid bone is uncommon (common in manual strangulation)

Thyroid cartilage

Fracture is less common

Fracture is more common

Cervical vertebrae

Fracture and/or dislocation common in judicial hanging

Fracture and/or dislocation—rare

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presented with swelling and tenderness over right leg after sports-related trauma. On examination, there is sensory loss and foot drop suggestive of injury to the common peroneal nerve. Fracture at which of the following sites is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to have fracture involving the neck of the fibula, which is closely related to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve can be rolled against the neck of the fibula. This nerve is commonly injured here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was admitted following a crush injury to his left leg. Two days later, his urine/plasma creatinine levels are < 20. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:

  • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT
  • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts
  • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI)
Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain has been diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the appropriate treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice for multiparous women of older age with chronic PID is Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: The incidence of a disease is 4 per 1000 of population with the average duration of 2 years. The prevalence is ________.
questions.solution:
Prevalence = 4/1000 (Incidence) x 2 (Mean Duration of Disease)= 8/1000 population

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: What is the effect on membrane when extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased?
questions.solution:
When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increased negativity of RMP.

RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusion depends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration of K+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+ rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell more negative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving the membrane hyperpolarised.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the fracture shown below, except:

choices.text: Strength of grip is significantly affected
It is caused by fall on outstretched hand
Cast is applied in James position

questions.solution:
The given image shows an extra-articular fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck i.e. Boxer's fracture. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing, or occasionally by a direct injury.

The strength of grip decreases in this fracture as the fourth and fifth fingers are responsible for the power grip of the hand.

The POP cast is applied in James' position/the position of safe immobilization for metacarpal fractures. This prevents stiffness and contractures as the ligaments are at their longest in this position.

Position of safe immobilization:

  • wrist slightly extended
  • the MCP joints in full flexion and the IP joints extended 
  • the thumb in abduction

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an example of point mutation?
questions.solution:
• The classic example of point mutation is sickle-cell disease.
  • This is a T-to-A DNA substitution, which in turn results in an A-to-U change in the mRNA corresponding to the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (Glutamic acid being replaced by valine).
  • Defective production of β-globin results in a variety of diseases and is due to many different lesions in and around the β-globin gene.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. These are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product.                                                                                                                                                      Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, β0 thalassemia.

Other options:

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

Related Pearl: Structural Alterations of the β -Globin Gene

Alteration

Function affected

Disease

Point Mutation

Protein folding

Sickle cell disease

Transcriptional control

β-Thalassemia

Frameshift & nonsense mutations

β-Thalassemia

RNA processing

β-Thalassemia

Deletion

mRNA production

β0-Thalassemia

Hemoglobin Lepore

Rearrangement

mRNA production

β-Thalassemia type III

questions.text: A neonate at birth falls in the 85th percentile when the weight is plotted on a standard intrauterine growth. This is called:
questions.solution:
A neonate whose weight falls in the 85th percentile on a standard intrauterine growth curve is termed as appropriate for gestational age.

The standard intrauterine growth curve plots the birth weight on the y-axis against the gestational age on the x-axis. Based on the graph below, newborns are classified as:

  • Appropriate for gestational age (AGA): 10th to 90th percentile
  • Small for gestational age (SGA): <10th percentile 
  • Large for gestational age (LGA:  > 90th percentile

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the death rate start declining?
questions.solution:
The death rate starts declining in stage 2 of the demographic cycle (early expanding phase).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 44-year-old female cook presents with a 1-year history of dyspnea, episodic cough, wheeze, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.  What is the best way to diagnose bronchial asthma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways.

Wheeze, dyspnoea, and reduced FEV1 values are nonspecific indicators of airway obstruction and are seen in any of the obstructive pathologies (i.e. asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis). Therefore, they do not independently diagnose asthma.

Whereas, the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist can differentiate between Asthma and COPD as follows:

  • >12% (200ml) increase in the FEV1 demonstrates the reversibility of airway obstruction which is diagnostic of bronchial asthma.
  • <12% or no increase in FEV1 demonstrates the irreversibility component of airway obstruction indicating COPD.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old kid with complaint that the child wakes up at night sweating and terrified, but is unable to recall the episode. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of night terrors. 

Night terrors (pavor nocturnus) is characterized by the following: 

  • Repetitive experiences of fright in which a person screams in fear during sleep (Usually normal in children). The person cannot be awakened.
  • Autonomic disturbances may be present.
  • The person has no memory of having a dream.
  • Occurs during delta sleep
  • Onset in adolescence may indicate temporal lobe epilepsy.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called Pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker
 Lighter
White matter
 Lighter  Darker
CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air
Dark
Dark
Cortical bone
Dark
Dark
Tendons and ligaments
Dark
Dark
Calcification
Dark
Dark
Flowing blood and hemosiderin
Dark
Dark

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
The given cannula is 20 gauge IV cannula as its color code is Pink.

The flow rate in cannula of this gauge is 67mL/minute

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida at 38 weeks in labor.  The obstetrician planned for a ventuse delivery because of maternal exhaustion.  She asked you to place the ventuse cup over the flexion point at the fetal scalp.  You locate the flexion point on______

choices.text: Sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
Sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior  fontanelle
Coronal suture 6 cm away from posterior fontanelle
Coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point, which is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.

Advantages of correct positioning of the cup in vacuum extraction:

  • Maximum traction.
  • Minimum cup detachment.
  • Twisting of the fetal head is avoided.
  • The smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet.
  • The success rate is improved.
  • Fetal scalp injury rates are lowered.
  • Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva

questions.text: Which is the most common organism implicated in the condition depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows rough finger-like growth over the vulva which is suggestive of condyloma acuminata. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

It is also called genital/venereal warts and has high infectivity. It is acquired most commonly after sexual contact but may also occur non-sexually.

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is anterior uveitis. The image shows keratic precipitates in the cornea and festooned pupil which are characteristic of anterior uveitis.

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the anterior portion of the uveal tract consisting of the iris and anterior ciliary body.

Anterior uveitis is characterized by: 

  • Koeppe nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at the pupillary margin
  • Busacca nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at collarette 
  • Keratic precipitates (KP) - proteinaceous deposits on the corneal endothelium. These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. Types of KP's include - 
    • Mutton fat type - seen in granulomatous uveitis
    • Granular type - seen in non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Aqueous flare - diffuse inflammation with exudates in the anterior chamber. It is the earliest sign of non-granulomatous uveitis

The exudates can also pour out into the posterior chamber causing the iris to adhere posteriorly to the lens. When the adhesions organize to become fibrous, it becomes firm and is known as posterior synechiae. 

A festooned pupil is an irregularly shaped pupil that is seen when segmental posterior synechiae are formed. When mydiatrics are administered in this condition, there is dilatation of the pupillary portions that have not yet adhered to the lens, leading to festooned pupil.

 

Other options:

Options A and C: Acute congestive glaucoma and acute conjunctivitis are both differential diagnoses for acute anterior uveitis. However, they do not have the characteristic feature of keratic precipitates.

Option D: Keratoconus or conical cornea is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic.

questions.text: NIH swab test is used in the diagnosis of which of the following parasites?
questions.solution:
NIH swab test is used in the diagnosis of pinworm a.k.a Enterobius vermicularis. Since pinworms are usually not released in feces, the fecal examination is not useful in the diagnosis. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. 

Man acquires Enterobius vermicularis infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. Infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus).

At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and crawls about on the perianal and perineal skin to lay its sticky eggs. This leads to pruritus, especially at night and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane is attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Another method of demonstrating eggs is the scotch tape method. Here, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides, and transferred to a glass slide. A drop of toluene is added and examined under the microscope.

Treatment: 

  • Albendazole 400 mg PO with a repeat dose 2 weeks
  • Frequent changing of underclothes, bedclothes, and bedsheets decreases environmental egg contamination and may decrease the risk for autoinfection.
  • Good hand hygiene is the most effective method of prevention.
The image given below shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

Related Pearl: Commonly known names of some important parasites

questions.text: Ashermans syndrome was diagnosed in a woman who presented with secondary amenorrhea. The hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. It is classified as___

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
30% adhesion is classified as moderate Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can be caused by the following:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

It causes secondary amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, habitual abortion and infertility depending upon the extent of uterine cavity obliteration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.
